channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: South Coast Plaza reopens for indoor shoppers as California relaxes some COVID-19 restrictions
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: South Coast Plaza, an upscale shopping center in Orange County, is reopening for indoor shopping again after an earlier coronavirus-related closure.
item.content:encoded: South Coast Plaza, an upscale shopping center in Orange County, is reopening for indoor shopping again after an earlier coronavirus-related closure.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA - JUNE 11: Due to social distancing, shoppers wear protective masks while waiting in line outside Louis Vuitton as South Coast Plaza reopens, requiring customers maintain a social distance and wear face masks at South Coast Plaza Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Costa Mesa, CA. Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's deadliest month of the COVID-19 pandemic is August
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: California has so far reported 3,707 deaths in August, amid signs of steady progress in reducing infections, hospitalizations and deaths, data show.
item.content:encoded: California has so far reported 3,707 deaths in August, amid signs of steady progress in reducing infections, hospitalizations and deaths, data show.

media:content.media:description: CHULA VISTA, CA - AUGUST 28: Jorge Angel Llamas (left) does a self swab Covid-19 test under the supervision of RN Karen Barringer (right) at the San Diego County Aquatica Testing Site on Friday, Aug. 28, 2020 in Chula Vista, CA. (Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune)
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Marine lured 14-year-old girl onto Twentynine Palms base for sex, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A Twentynine Palms Marine was arrested on suspicion of statutory rape last week after authorities said he lured a 14-year-old girl to the base.
item.content:encoded: A Twentynine Palms Marine was arrested on suspicion of statutory rape last week after authorities said he lured a 14-year-old girl to the base.

media:content.media:description: The Twentynine Palms Marine combat training base.

item.title: Porn star Ron Jeremy charged with 20 more counts of sexual abuse in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Since Ron Jeremy was charged with sex assault in late June, dozens have reached out to detectives and the media saying he attacked them too.
item.content:encoded: Since Ron Jeremy was charged with sex assault in late June, dozens have reached out to detectives and the media saying he attacked them too.

media:content.media:description: Adult film star Ron Jeremy talks with his attorney Stuart Goldfarb during his arraignment on rape and sexual assault charges at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center, Friday, June 26, 2020, in Los Angeles. Jeremy pleaded not guilty to charges of raping three women and sexually assaulting a fourth. (David McNew/Pool Photo via AP)

item.title: L.A. and Airbnb launch system meant to help with enforcing rental rules
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Los Angeles and Airbnb have launched a new system meant to help the city ferret out and remove illegal listings from the online platform.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles and Airbnb have launched a new system meant to help the city ferret out and remove illegal listings from the online platform.

media:content.media:description: Dozens of Venice residents and advocates rally on the Venice Boardwalk on Aug. 3, 2015, to call on the Los Angeles City Council to regulate short-term rentals, such as those from Airbnb.

item.title: In latest house party shooting, 23-year-old man is killed in Arcadia
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Arcadia incident is the latest in a string of shootings at house parties in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: The Arcadia incident is the latest in a string of shootings at house parties in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA CA. AUGUST 31, 2020 - An investigation is underway Monday morning, August 31, 2020, after a shooting at an Arcadia house party left one man dead Sunday night. Arcadia police would only identified the victim as a man in his 20s, who suffered multiple gunshot wounds. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: California could soon end its dumb policy on inmate firefighters. What took so long?
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: After years of pushing, the California Legislature passed a bill to help former prisoners become full-time firefighters. The governor should sign it.
item.content:encoded: After years of pushing, the California Legislature passed a bill to help former prisoners become full-time firefighters. The governor should sign it.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-AUGUST 24, 2020: Joshua McKinney, 26, left, and Eric Hunt, 41, are photographed at Joshua's grandmother's home in Los Angeles on Monday, August 24, 2020. The two are former inmate firefighters who want to go back to fighting fires, but can't because of legal barriers over their criminal records. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAUSD enrollment decline continues during online learning, with unexpected drop of 6,000 kindergarteners
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Principals and district officials are concerned about enrollment numbers in the L.A. Unified School District, especially among the youngest students.
item.content:encoded: Principals and district officials are concerned about enrollment numbers in the L.A. Unified School District, especially among the youngest students.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 14: School Coordinator Lali Oustinovskaya, right, talks with parent Byata Dikker, left, before she leaves a technology and supply pickup event before the start of the school year at Gardner Elementary School on Friday, Aug. 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County sheriff's prisoner transport bus strikes and kills pedestrian on 5 Freeway
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A stretch of the northbound 5 Freeway was closed near Arleta for nearly five hours, but all lanes reopened shortly before 8 a.m.
item.content:encoded: A stretch of the northbound 5 Freeway was closed near Arleta for nearly five hours, but all lanes reopened shortly before 8 a.m.

media:content.media:description: An investigation is underway after a Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department inmate transport bus struck and killed a pedestrian Monday morning on the 5 Freeway in the Arleta area, Monday morning, August 31, 2020.

item.title: At Monterey Bay Aquarium, the sea animals are doing great, but business is tanking
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: The iconic Monterey Bay Aquarium has been closed since March because of the pandemic, forcing major cutbacks. Still, the animals must be cared for.
item.content:encoded: The iconic Monterey Bay Aquarium has been closed since March because of the pandemic, forcing major cutbacks. Still, the animals must be cared for.

media:content.media:description: MONTEREY, CA - AUGUST 20: Rey, a penguin, looks out at the Kelp Forest tank while stopping near Senior Aviculturist Kim Fukuda, 46, of Marina, while Rey takes a stroll in the aquarium outside of the penguin enclosure at the Monterey Bay Aquarium on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020 in Monterey, CA. The aquarium has been closed to the public until further notice due to the ongoing Coronavirus Pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Can you trust the police to tell the truth? Reliability under scrutiny as cases tossed
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: As cases are tossed or rejected by prosecutors, the reliability of police accounts increasingly is being challenged amid a push for criminal justice reform.
item.content:encoded: As cases are tossed or rejected by prosecutors, the reliability of police accounts increasingly is being challenged amid a push for criminal justice reform.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17: Lyle Spruill, 45, poses in his home in South Los Angeles on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Spruill is suing the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Dept., saying that deputies fabricated a story that he shot at them and then falsely arrested him for attempted murder. He was in jail for six months after the Dec. 2019 incident and is now trying to put his life back together. Finding work as a trained welder is difficult for Spruill because his charges show up whenever a potential employer does a background check. He advises people to "be more cautious and stay woke. A lot of bad things happen to people that go under the radar." He went onto say "I hope to come out of it and bring awareness to it (the Sheriff's Dept.) and maybe someone else will be treated better." (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: In this year's atypical California fire season, politicians find the blame game won't work
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: A cardinal rule of politics and punditry is to clearly state the problem, point out who's at fault and say what should be done about it. But with the current wildfires, it's Mother Nature's handiwork.
item.content:encoded: A cardinal rule of politics and punditry is to clearly state the problem, point out who's at fault and say what should be done about it. But with the current wildfires, it's Mother Nature's handiwork.

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - In this long exposure photograph, flames consumes both sides of a segment of Lake Berryessa during the Hennessey fire in the Spanish Flat area of Napa, California on August 18, 2020. - As of the late hours of August 18, the Hennessey fire has merged with at least 7 fires and is now called the LNU Lightning Complex fires. Dozens of fires are burning out of control throughout Northern California as fire resources are spread thin. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California corporations would be required to diversify their boards under bill sent to Newsom
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers on Sunday sent the governor a bill that would require greater diversity on corporate boards in the state, saying the shortage of people of color is a hurdle to racial justice.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers on Sunday sent the governor a bill that would require greater diversity on corporate boards in the state, saying the shortage of people of color is a hurdle to racial justice.

media:content.media:description: California corporate boards would have to diversify under legislation sent to the governor.

item.title: Anaheim police fatally shoot man sought on arrest warrant
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: He allegedly armed himself with a kitchen knife, prompting one or more officers to open fire, according to investigators.
item.content:encoded: He allegedly armed himself with a kitchen knife, prompting one or more officers to open fire, according to investigators.

media:content.media:description: Jesse David Nava, 25.

item.title: L.A. County reports 1,030 new COVID-19 cases, while hospitalizations continue dropping
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: There were 1,089 confirmed coronavirus patients in county hospitals as of Sunday — the lowest number since early May — with 32% in intensive care.
item.content:encoded: There were 1,089 confirmed coronavirus patients in county hospitals as of Sunday — the lowest number since early May — with 32% in intensive care.

media:content.media:description: Melanie Olmeda and her six-year-old son Mason Gutierrez, who are zoo members, drove from Chino for the reopening on Wednesday.

item.title: Confusion after LAPD responds to reports of gunfire at pro-Trump car caravan
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Richard Winton, Angel Jennings, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Reports of gunfire at a pro-Trump caravan led to a police standoff at an apartment building in Woodland Hills, but SWAT officers found no one in the apartment.
item.content:encoded: Reports of gunfire at a pro-Trump caravan led to a police standoff at an apartment building in Woodland Hills, but SWAT officers found no one in the apartment.

media:content.media:description: Studio City, CA. August 30, 2020: An LAPD officer and a Trump supporter walk across the street in opposite direections between two groups of protesters. Earlier a caravan rally of supporters of President Donald Trumpdrove up and down Ventura Blvd starting in Woodland Hills and concluded in Studio City, CA Sunday August 30, 2020. Drivers help flags, honked their horns, and stood out of sunroofs. At the end of the event there were about 100 Pro Trump supporters on one side of the street and pro BLM supporters on the opposite side of the street. The gathering was physically peaceful and with verbal exchanges. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California lawmakers vote to phase out toxic firefighting foam
item.dc:creator: Anna M. Phillips
item.description: Senate bill requires fire departments, chemical plants and oil refineries to phase out a toxic firefighting foam
item.content:encoded: Senate bill requires fire departments, chemical plants and oil refineries to phase out a toxic firefighting foam

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - MAY 9, 2016: ExxonMobil planned to fire up a key part of the Torrance refinery that helps process gasoline on Monday night. As part of its start-up procedure, Exxon Mobil plans to turn off the refinery's pollution control system for six hours during a 12-hour period, a step approved by the South Coast Air Quality Management District as a safety precaution. (Michael Owen Baker / For The Times)
media:content.media:credit: Michael Owen Baker / Michael Owen Baker / For The Tim

item.title: California Democrats scuttle wildfire utility fee plan, turn to Newsom in last-ditch effort
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: The California Legislature abandoned a bill to extend a fee on utility customers to generate $500 million for wildfire projects.
item.content:encoded: The California Legislature abandoned a bill to extend a fee on utility customers to generate $500 million for wildfire projects.

media:content.media:description: Flames from the River Fire crest a ridge as firefighters Ian Johnson, right, and Capt. Mike Campbell protects a home in Salinas, Calif., on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of blazes sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heatwave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Man shot and killed on 405 Freeway in Seal Beach
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Officers found a light blue Hyundai Elantra in the center divider area; inside was a man in his mid-20s who appeared to have suffered a gunshot wound.
item.content:encoded: Officers found a light blue Hyundai Elantra in the center divider area; inside was a man in his mid-20s who appeared to have suffered a gunshot wound.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - FEBRUARY 01: A California Highway Patrol vehicle waits to turn onto Washington blvd after departing the CHP Office near downtown Los Angeles, on Friday, Feb. 1, 2019 in Los Angeles, Calif. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ex-deputy's murder charge is first in California under new use-of-force law
item.dc:creator: Greg Moran
item.description: The new law changes the standard for when police can use deadly force from when 'reasonable' to prevent imminent, serious injury or death — to when 'necessary.'
item.content:encoded: The new law changes the standard for when police can use deadly force from when 'reasonable' to prevent imminent, serious injury or death — to when 'necessary.'

media:content.media:description: Former sheriff's deputy Aaron Russell, (L) listens from jail during his video arraignment in San Diego Superior Court on Tuesday. (Nicholas Peter Bils while he was running from officers. Russell's attorneys, Richard Pinckard (bottom left), Michael Begovich, (bottom right), Deputy District Attorney Stephen Marquardt (top right)) Russell, 23, pleaded not guilty to a charge of murder in the May 1 death of Nicholas Bils, who was shot near San Diego Central Jail while fleeing custody.
media:content.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/For The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Hundreds converge on East Los Angeles for 50th anniversary of Chicano Moratorium
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Doug Smith, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Issues such as racial injustice and police brutality, protested at the Chicano Moratorium in 1970, remain painfully relevant today, marchers said.
item.content:encoded: Issues such as racial injustice and police brutality, protested at the Chicano Moratorium in 1970, remain painfully relevant today, marchers said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 29, 2020. Brown Berets joinhundreds of people gathered at Ruben Salazar Park in Los Angeles on Saturday, Aug. 29, 2020, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium and the death of Mexican-American journalist Ruiben Salazar. The moratorium was a march to call attention to the disproportionate number of Latinos killed while serving in the Vietnam War. A reporter for the Los Angeles Times, Salazar was killed by police while covering the anti-war march and rally. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: He paved the way for big electronic billboards. Then $75,000 poured in for his reelection
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Curren Price helped a developer obtain approval for electronic signs. The developer's companies spent $75,000 to reelect Price.
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Curren Price helped a developer obtain approval for electronic signs. The developer's companies spent $75,000 to reelect Price.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 26: A digital sign is on Sunday, July 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The light from the billboard streams into neighboring apartments, keeping people up at night. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Police PR machine under scrutiny for inaccurate reporting, alleged pro-cop bias
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau
item.description: Amid calls to defund police, the public relations machine within law enforcement is coming under scrutiny.
item.content:encoded: Amid calls to defund police, the public relations machine within law enforcement is coming under scrutiny.

item.title: Could the coronavirus make for a lighter flu season?

item.description: The social distancing that tamps down the coronavirus could also keep many people from getting the flu.
item.content:encoded: The social distancing that tamps down the coronavirus could also keep many people from getting the flu.

media:content.media:description: It's time for the seasonal flu shot.

item.title: Why California's 2020 lightning fires got so big so fast
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: California has a long history of lightning-caused fires, but 2020 is showing how a changing climate can affect the growth of such blazes.
item.content:encoded: California has a long history of lightning-caused fires, but 2020 is showing how a changing climate can affect the growth of such blazes.

media:content.media:description: BOULDER CREEK, CA - AUGUST 23: Firefighters respond to a structure fire along Riverdale boulevard as the fire line creeps up on Highway 9 during the CZU Lightning complex fire on Sunday, Aug. 23, 2020 in Boulder Creek, CA (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The pandemic is speeding DMV's road to modernization. For visitors, it's still no day at the beach
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic has pushed the California DMV to expand online services such as title transfers, registrations and driver's license renewals, reducing the need for people to wait in person at a field office.
item.content:encoded: The COVID-19 pandemic has pushed the California DMV to expand online services such as title transfers, registrations and driver's license renewals, reducing the need for people to wait in person at a field office.

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CA - AUGUST 13: Guillermo Torres, left, administers an eye test at DMV on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Westminster, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Foster Farms to temporarily close poultry plant after 8 workers die of COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Foster Farms announced Saturday it would temporarily close one of a California poultry plant where a coronavirus outbreak has left eight workers dead.
item.content:encoded: Foster Farms announced Saturday it would temporarily close one of a California poultry plant where a coronavirus outbreak has left eight workers dead.

media:content.media:description: Mexico is the top export market for U.S. poultry. The ban of Foster Farms chicken from three facilities is believed to be the first time Mexico has responded in such a way to a U.S. health alert.

item.title: Fans turn out for vigil in Leimert Park for actor Chadwick Boseman
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Boseman made a career out of playing historic Black figures, including the "Godfather of Soul" James Brown, Dodgers great Jackie Robinson and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.
item.content:encoded: Boseman made a career out of playing historic Black figures, including the "Godfather of Soul" James Brown, Dodgers great Jackie Robinson and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA AUGUST 29, 2020-Fans of Chadwick Boseman chant "Wakanda forever" in refernce to the movie "Black Panther" during a memorial for the late actor at Leimert Park Saturday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Pro-Trump supporters and counter-protesters squared off in the streets in a skirmish that ended with one person being arrested, the latest in a series of demonstrations in the city.

item.content:encoded: Staff Sgt. Vincent Marketta and Sgt. Tyler Shelton died when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed during training off the Southern California coast.

media:content.media:description: Staff Sgt. Vincent Marketta, left, and Sgt. Tyler Shelton, right, were killed Thursday when their Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed on San Clemente Island during training.

item.title: Hundreds gather in East L.A. to mark anniversary of Chicano Moratorium
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Doug Smith, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A series of marches, forums and screenings are being held throughout Los Angeles on Saturday to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium.

item.title: When can schools reopen under new state rules? It's all about color-coded tiers and waivers
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Phil Willon
item.description: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.
item.content:encoded: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, left, is given a tour Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, right, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Fired as a hotel housekeeper when she got COVID-19, she now has no income or healthcare
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.
item.content:encoded: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26, 2020 - - Arturo Mejia, 30, from left, his wife Liz, 30, holding hens, and their daughters Zoe, 7, and Eva, 5, stand in the backyard of their home where they are growing squash, peppers, tomatoes and herbs in South Los Angeles on August 26, 2020. Liz Mejia was laid off 5 months ago working as a waitress at a restaurant at LAX. Arturo is currently working as a jet mechanic for Delta Airlines. The Mejia family have been saving money by growing their own vegetables and raising hens for eggs. They joined other family members and bought a cow that they had slaughtered for food. They said that they had meat in the house for 3 months. They also had the pet goat slaughtered for meat. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Summer at the Hollywood Bowl, 2020: No concerts but food boxes for the hungry
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.
item.content:encoded: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 27: Aracely Rendon, 42, has her dog "Max" and a friend to keep her company as she waits in line with vehicles lining up early as the Hollywood Bowl has been transformed into a drive-thru food distribution on Thursday's in a season when the concerts are canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The drive-thru food distribution is organized by L.A. County, with major help from the L.A. Regional Food Bank on Thursday mornings where people are able to drive in and get several boxes of food - meat, vegetables, fruit, pantry items - put into the trunks of their vehicles by volunteers or LA County employees who have been re-assigned to help because of a work slow down in their other County positions. Hollywood Bowl on Thursday, Aug. 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Holocaust reparations, prescriptions and rent checks: USPS delays put Americans in jeopardy
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service — all have been stalled.
item.content:encoded: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service — all have been stalled.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-AUGUST 26, 2020: A mail carrier loads a truck for delivery at a United States Post Office in Torrance on Wednesday, August 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County wants justices to reopen schools statewide. Experts say it's a long shot
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: FILE — In this March 12, 2020 file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks to reporters about the state's response to the coronavirus during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat who leads the nation's most populous state, has won praise from both sides of the aisle for his approach to the coronavirus crisis though he's been less aggressive than some other governors and local leaders. Newsom is accompanied by California Department of Public Heath Director and State Health Officer Dr Sonia Angell, left, and California Health and Human Services Agency Director Dr. Mark Ghaly, right. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Here's how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will affect you
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you
item.content:encoded: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 9, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom wears a protective mask on his face while speaking to reporters at Miss Ollie's restaurant during the coronavirus outbreak in Oakland, Calif. According to a new poll, Americans overwhelmingly are in favor of requiring people to wear masks around other people outside their homes, reflecting fresh alarm over spiking infection rates. The poll also shows increasing disapproval of the federal government's response to the pandemic. California is among the states seeing the greatest surge in cases now. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, Pool, File)

item.title: San Francisco announces plans for outdoor hair and nail services, with outdoor gyms to follow
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.

media:content.media:description: Marathon runners would cross the Golden State Bridge if San Francisco is selected to host the 2024 Olympic Games.

item.title: California lawmakers reach deal for new eviction protections that would last through January
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.
item.content:encoded: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 05: A housing rights and anti-eviction protest outside the office of attorney Dennis Block in Valley Village on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, attracted about 35 protesters. Block has evicted more than 200,000 tenants since 1976, according to the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, the parent of nonprofit Housing is a Human Right and Healthy Housing Foundation, the organizers of the protest. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, dies at 93
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, gave talks at AA meetings from South Dakota to Iceland and sponsored thousands.
item.content:encoded: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, gave talks at AA meetings from South Dakota to Iceland and sponsored thousands.

media:content.media:description: Clancy Imislund

item.title: Thief racks up more than $1,400 on credit cards stolen from firefighter, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.
item.content:encoded: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.

media:content.media:description: Brian Johnson, 37, of Live Oak has been arrested on suspicion of stealing a firefighter's wallet earlier this month.

item.title: Newsom unveils sweeping new coronavirus reopening rules for businesses in California
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.
item.content:encoded: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.

item.title: TikTok stars charged with misdemeanors related to Hollywood parties during pandemic
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are charged with misdemeanors for allegedly holding large parties in the Hollywood Hills during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are charged with misdemeanors for allegedly holding large parties in the Hollywood Hills during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Atty. Mike Feuer issued a warning about immigration scams, saying that if an offer seems too good to be true, it probably is.

item.title: Protesters plaster signs at LAPD chief's home during another night of demonstrations
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: An LAPD spokeswoman confirmed Friday morning that officers responded to Moore's home and took a vandalism report, but said no arrests had been made.
item.content:encoded: An LAPD spokeswoman confirmed Friday morning that officers responded to Moore's home and took a vandalism report, but said no arrests had been made.

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators once again took to the streets of downtown Los Angeles as a crowd of roughly 150 to 200 people marched in the area around L.A. City Hall.

item.title: California lawmakers vote to expand ban on death penalty for intellectually disabled people
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: California legislators vote to expand a law prohibiting the death penalty against intellectually disabled defendants. The bill now goes to Gov. Gavin Newsom.
item.content:encoded: California legislators vote to expand a law prohibiting the death penalty against intellectually disabled defendants. The bill now goes to Gov. Gavin Newsom.

media:content.media:description: A death row inmate is escorted back to his East Block cell after spending time in the yard at San Quentin State Prison on Aug. 16.

item.title: California vs. Trump hits the 100-lawsuit mark with new challenge to environmental rules
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California reached a milestone Friday in its ongoing legal feud with President Trump when Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra announced he had filed his 100th lawsuit against the administration, this time challenging changes in environmental rules.
item.content:encoded: California reached a milestone Friday in its ongoing legal feud with President Trump when Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra announced he had filed his 100th lawsuit against the administration, this time challenging changes in environmental rules.

media:content.media:description: California Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra said the state has joined others as a plaintiff in a lawsuit challenging the Trump administration's latest travel ban.

item.title: Mail delivery suspended at L.A. public housing complex with over 1,800 residents
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Mail delivery has been cut off at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, and residents must now collect their mail more than a mile away.
item.content:encoded: Mail delivery has been cut off at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, and residents must now collect their mail more than a mile away.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 18: Daisy Vega, president of the resident advisory council at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, poses for a portrait in front of her apartment in Mar Vista Gardens on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. She is worried about a possible change in mail delivery that would stop bringing letters to residents' doors, instead bringing them to centralized banks of mailboxes in the complex. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Preschoolers are mask-licking germ bombs — yet few catch the coronavirus, data show
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: It's hard to predict what may happen when California's primary schools reopen. But when it comes to the state's youngest students, data are more robust and reassuring.
item.content:encoded: It's hard to predict what may happen when California's primary schools reopen. But when it comes to the state's youngest students, data are more robust and reassuring.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-AUGUST 27, 2020: A child wears a mask while painting at Voyages Preschool in Los Angeles on Thursday, August 27, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAUSD's liberal student attendance policy raises eyebrows
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Taking attendance at L.A. schools amid online learning is far more complicated -- and a lot more liberal -- than saying "here" when a student's name is called.
item.content:encoded: Taking attendance at L.A. schools amid online learning is far more complicated -- and a lot more liberal -- than saying "here" when a student's name is called.

media:content.media:description: EAGLE ROCK, CA - AUGUST 21: Los Angeles Unified School District Eagle Rock Jr./Sr. High School history teacher Alice Lee interacts virtually with students as they participate in class on the second day of school in LAUSD. Los Angeles on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Eagle Rock, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: 50 years after the Chicano Moratorium, a Mexican American veteran on what it meant to fight in the war
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: He was in Vietnam, a young Mexican American soldier, when thousands of demonstrators marched in East Los Angeles against the war and other injustices.
item.content:encoded: He was in Vietnam, a young Mexican American soldier, when thousands of demonstrators marched in East Los Angeles against the war and other injustices.

media:content.media:description: Rowland Heights, CA, August 24, 2020 - Vietnam veteran Tom Sandoval lived in Lincoln Heights and was in Vietnam during the August 29 Chicano Moratorium march. The National Chicano Moratorium Committee Against The Vietnam War, was a movement of Chicano anti-war activists that built a broad-based coalition of Mexican-American groups to organize opposition to the Vietnam War. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Monopoly, video games, study groups: How COVID-19 is spreading at USC
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Small gatherings, like students studying together and, in one case, playing games like Monopoly, have led to a surge in COVID-19 cases on USC lately.
item.content:encoded: Small gatherings, like students studying together and, in one case, playing games like Monopoly, have led to a surge in COVID-19 cases on USC lately.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 20: USC students Ethan Recinto, 21, of Illinois and Robert Beyer, 21, of New Jersey pose outside University Gateway Apartments on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. University Gateway has a reputation as a party location and that hasn't changed despite coronavirus.(Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dangers of third coronavirus surge in California focus on young people, essential workers
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee
item.description: California health officials prepare for a potential third surge of coronavirus cases fueled by essential workers and young people.
item.content:encoded: California health officials prepare for a potential third surge of coronavirus cases fueled by essential workers and young people.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 08: People enjoy a hike with amazing views in Kenneth Hahn park on a summer weekend in Los Angeles during the coronavirus pandemic Saturday, Aug. 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Friday at 4:26 a.m. Pacific time 10 miles from Calexico, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Heffernan: Kimberly Guilfoyle shows our way of looking at high society and power is broken
item.dc:creator: Virginia Heffernan
item.description: Maybe this century's bipartisan obsession with vulgar preening will be bookended by Guilfoyle's 2004 "New Kennedys" photo and her freeze-frame meme from the 2020 RNC.
item.content:encoded: Maybe this century's bipartisan obsession with vulgar preening will be bookended by Guilfoyle's 2004 "New Kennedys" photo and her freeze-frame meme from the 2020 RNC.

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - AUGUST 24: Kimberly Guilfoyle pre-records her address to the Republican National Convention at the Mellon Auditorium August 24, 2020 in Washington, DC. The novel coronavirus pandemic has forced the Republican Party to move away from an in-person convention to a televised format, similar to the Democratic Party's convention a week earlier. (Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

item.title: After 8 workers die of COVID-19, officials want Merced County Foster Farms plant closed

item.content:encoded: After 8 workers die of coronavirus, officials want Foster Farms plant closed

item.title: Officer alleges LAPD had quotas, silenced whistleblowers in gang-labeling scandal
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Ben Poston
item.description: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.
item.content:encoded: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.

item.content:encoded: Orange County is expected to receive the green light for in-person learning at all schools just before Labor Day if the county continues to remain off the state's watchlist.

item.title: Lane Hirabayashi, scholar who refused to let Japanese American prison camps be forgotten, dies at 67

item.description: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.
item.content:encoded: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.

item.content:encoded: Attorneys for the family of Anthony McClain say he was not armed when police shot him in the back as he ran.

item.title: New $300-a-week unemployment benefits coming soon, California officials say
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.
item.content:encoded: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.

item.title: Police unions ask Legislature to hold special session for reforms

item.description: Police unions in Los Angeles and San Francisco Thursday asked Gov. Gavin Newsom to convene a special session of the Legislature before passing new reforms.
item.content:encoded: Police unions in Los Angeles and San Francisco Thursday asked Gov. Gavin Newsom to convene a special session of the Legislature before passing new reforms.

item.title: Rat poison kills bobcat, mountain lion in Southern California mountains
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.
item.content:encoded: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.

media:content.media:description: The body of B-372, an adult female bobcat, was found June 20, 2020, in Agoura Hills. Officials said she died from the effects of anticoagulant rat poisons.

item.title: Beverly Hills will prosecute protesters for curfew violations
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.
item.content:encoded: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA JUNE 6, 2020-A family member of Breonna Taylor, right, is hugged by another woman after speaking to protestors in beverly Hills Saturday. The protest was organzied by the Refuse Fascism group. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Senate Republicans under COVID-19 quarantine, not allowed in state Capitol
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez, Taryn Luna
item.description: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.
item.content:encoded: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Contra Costa County allows gyms, nail salons and massage services to reopen outdoors
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.
item.content:encoded: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT CREEK, CALIFORNIA - JULY 21: Insignia Hair Salon stylist Regina Muslimova cleans her station after giving a haircut in the parking lot behind her salon on July 21, 2020 in Walnut Creek, California. The salon reopened its doors to clients for haircuts a day after California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced guidance for barbershops and hair salons to offer haircuts in an outdoor setting. According to the new guidelines, "outdoor operations may be conducted under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter as long as no more than one side is closed, allowing sufficient outdoor air movement." (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: How Los Angeles is commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium
item.description: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.
item.content:encoded: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Martina Ibáñez-Baldor / Los Angeles Times. Photographs from from Los Angeles Times, Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Raul Ruiz, and Special Collections & Archives, John F. Kennedy Memorial Library, Cal State LA, Gloria Arellanes Papers.

item.title: 10 arrested after protesters clash with L.A. police in wake of Jacob Blake shooting
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Richard Winton, Leila Miller
item.description: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday
item.content:encoded: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 26, 2020 - Protesters raise their hands as LAPD officers converge on them from both sides in the Third St. underpass. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California adopts major pollution cuts for diesel trucks and ships
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.
item.content:encoded: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. AUGUST 27, 2020 - Trucks line up to drop off their loads at the Port of Los Angeles in August 28, 2020. California air quality officials are poised to adopt their biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade, targeting diesel trucks and cargo ships that spew much of the state's cancer-causing and smog-forming emissions. The state Air Resources Board is expected to vote after a public hearing Thursday on two rules: one to establish stringent new emissions standards for heavy-duty diesel trucks and one to reduce pollution from ships docked at ports. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. teacher flees home amid threats after wearing 'I can't breathe' T-shirt to online class
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.
item.content:encoded: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - AUGUST 26: Students and community members protest in front of El Camino Charter High School to show support a teacher who wore an 'I can't breathe' shirt while teaching a class on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. Zoo reopens, but visitors have to stay one zebra apart
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Meerkats look at the visitors to the reopening of the Los Angeles Zoo on Wednesday. The zoo had been closed since March 13, 2020 because of the coronavirus pandemic. The reopening conforms with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health's safety protocols that include limited capacity, timed-ticketed entry, closure of indoor and high-touch spaces, requirements for face coverings and supplemental signage throughout the zoo.

item.title: Dodgers announcer Jaime Jarrín: Chicano Moratorium eyewitness
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime Jarrín was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.
item.content:encoded: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime Jarrín was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.

media:content.media:description: SAN MARINO-CA-AUGUST 18, 2020: Dodger broadcaster Jaime Jarrin, left, and his son Jorge are photographed with their Golden Mike awards for excellence in radio news coverage at home in San Marino on Tuesday, August 18, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Many California police reform efforts have stalled despite push from George Floyd protests
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.
item.content:encoded: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JUNE 04: Protest over police brutality and the death of George Floyd takes place in front of North Hollywood Police Station. Rally was organized by Showing up for Racial Justice (SURJ), an organization dedicated to organizing white folks across the nation to show up and fight the root causes of racism. North Hollywood Police Station on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Through doll play, an L.A. therapist reminds Black girls of their innocence
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.
item.content:encoded: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, California-MARCH 5, 2020: Renee Curry, a therapist, leads a group of Crete Academy students during a therapy session at Crete Academy in Park Mesa Heights. For an hour each Thursday afternoon, the group of four or five girls play with dolls and talk about anything from their home dynamics to their friends at school. The idea is to give these girls a space to experience their own innocence in an attempt to at least partially address the effects of adultification bias (a form of racial prejudice where children of minority groups, particularly black girls, are treated as being more mature than they actually are by a reasonable social standard of development). (Gabriella Angotti-Jones/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Watch the L.A. Times Chicano Moratorium forum live
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.
item.content:encoded: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Times hosted a virtual community forum Aug. 27 on the Chicano Moratorium, an anti-Vietnam War march held 50 years ago this month that played pivotal role in the fight for civil rights in Los Angeles. Hosted by Times editor Steve Padilla, the forum guests include reporters Daniel Hernandez, former Times reporter Robert Lopez and Carolina Miranda.

item.title: Workers and customers are catching COVID-19. Should businesses escape blame?
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.
item.content:encoded: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CA - AUGUST 12: Henry Ephraim poses for a portrait outside the Ralphs/Food 4 Less distribution center in Compton where he says he caught the coronavirus due to the companies failure to institute safety measures for its workers on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Compton, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus has turned once-bustling downtown L.A. into a ghost town. Can it recover?
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.
item.content:encoded: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 6, 2020. A man pushes a shopping cart along the sidewalk in the historc urban core of Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020. Motor and foot traffic downtown has thinned considerably since the pre-coronavirus days of five months ago. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: Newsom proves he's no deer in headlights while managing several crises 'of biblical proportions'
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic — a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.
item.content:encoded: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic — a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.

media:content.media:description: Aug. 17, 2020 - California Gov. Gavin Newsom briefing on the power outages in the state due to extreme heat.
media:content.media:credit: Office of the Governor of California

item.title: Former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy charged with assault, theft while on duty
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy faces criminal charges for hitting a man with a baseball bat, filing a false police report and stealing from a Big 5 Sporting Goods store during unrest in June after the death of George Floyd
item.content:encoded: A former San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy faces criminal charges for hitting a man with a baseball bat, filing a false police report and stealing from a Big 5 Sporting Goods store during unrest in June after the death of George Floyd

item.title: L.A. County CEO to receive $1.5 million and security in settlement over alleged harassment by sheriff
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.
item.content:encoded: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.

media:content.media:description: LA County agrees to pay $1.5 million to Sachi Hamai after she was harassed by Sheriff Alex Villanueva.

item.title: O.C. sheriff's sergeant accidentally fires weapon at airport, injuring employee
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: An Orange County sheriff's sergeant accidentally fired his weapon in the John Wayne Airport on Wednesday morning, injuring an airport employee.
item.content:encoded: An Orange County sheriff's sergeant accidentally fired his weapon in the John Wayne Airport on Wednesday morning, injuring an airport employee.

media:content.media:description: A jet passes over the 405 Freeway as it approaches John Wayne Airport.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Police in L.A. region announce dozens of arrests and ongoing pursuit of suspects from summer unrest
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Police from across the Los Angeles region announced Wednesday the arrests of dozens of people on arson, burglary and looting charges stemming from the unrest of late May and early June.
item.content:encoded: Police from across the Los Angeles region announced Wednesday the arrests of dozens of people on arson, burglary and looting charges stemming from the unrest of late May and early June.

item.title: Protesters march in downtown L.A. over Jacob Blake shooting
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Hundreds of protesters rallied near the Hall of Justice in downtown L.A. on Wednesday evening as nationwide demonstrations continue over the police shooting of Jacob Blake and the killing of two people at a protest in Kenosha, Wis.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of protesters rallied near the Hall of Justice in downtown L.A. on Wednesday evening as nationwide demonstrations continue over the police shooting of Jacob Blake and the killing of two people at a protest in Kenosha, Wis.

media:content.media:description: In this September 2019 selfie photo taken in Evanston, Ill., Adria-Joi Watkins poses with her second cousin Jacob Blake. He is recovering from being shot multiple times by Kenosha police on Aug. 23. (Courtesy Adria-Joi Watkins via AP)

item.title: A second L.A. Metro bus driver has died of complications from COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The driver, a 22-year veteran of the agency, most recently drove on Line 611, through Cudahy and Huntington Park.
item.content:encoded: The driver, a 22-year veteran of the agency, most recently drove on Line 611, through Cudahy and Huntington Park.

media:content.media:description: An L.A. Metro bus motors down Third Street in downtown Los Angeles on Aug. 7, 2015.

item.title: L.A. County reports cases of newborns with COVID-19 for first time
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Of the 193 babies who were tested at birth, eight were positive.
item.content:encoded: Of the 193 babies who were tested at birth, eight were positive.

media:content.media:description: A new study suggests stressed out women are less likely to get pregnant than women with lower stress.
media:content.media:credit: Myrtle Beach Sun News / Associated Press

item.title: Protesters surround tents, block streets to stop major cleanup of Hollywood homeless encampment
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Activists took to the streets of Hollywood to protest "comprehensive cleanups" of homeless encampments and demand that L.A. leaders commandeer hotels to house people living on the streets.
item.content:encoded: Activists took to the streets of Hollywood to protest "comprehensive cleanups" of homeless encampments and demand that L.A. leaders commandeer hotels to house people living on the streets.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26: Services Not Sweeps coalition members surround a tent to stop city workers from removing it during a homeless encampment sweep on Cherokee Avenue on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California could see a quarter-million coronavirus tests a day under new state plan
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The expanded coronavirus testing capacity and quicker results will increase the ability of officials to quickly isolate people who test positive and to track down those who came in contact with them, California Gov. Gavin Newsom said.
item.content:encoded: The expanded coronavirus testing capacity and quicker results will increase the ability of officials to quickly isolate people who test positive and to track down those who came in contact with them, California Gov. Gavin Newsom said.

media:content.media:description: Newsom

item.title: Most nursing home inspectors still haven't been tested for the coronavirus, despite Newsom pledge
item.dc:creator: Jack Dolan, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Newsom ordered the testing after an L.A. Times investigation found that health officials had been sending inspectors to nursing homes without testing.
item.content:encoded: Newsom ordered the testing after an L.A. Times investigation found that health officials had been sending inspectors to nursing homes without testing.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA - MARCH 25: A worker at Eisenberg Village nursing home screens all incoming for symptoms of the coronavirus on Wednesday, March 25, 2020 in Reseda, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California officials oppose CDC over looser coronavirus testing and travel protocols
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Phil Willon
item.description: As the CDC pulled back recommendations on quarantines for travelers and testing for those exposed to the virus, local officials spoke out.
item.content:encoded: As the CDC pulled back recommendations on quarantines for travelers and testing for those exposed to the virus, local officials spoke out.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 25: From center: Hugo Pena monitors Kendall McCrory as she donates blood during L.A. Care's blood drive in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Red Cross recently announced that it had a ``dangerous drop in blood supply'' due to the more than 30,000 blood drives that have been canceled since March because of the COIVID-19 pandemic. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Senate abruptly halts work due to a new coronavirus case
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: A memo asked senators and staff to 'hold in place' in their offices or homes after state Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: A memo asked senators and staff to 'hold in place' in their offices or homes after state Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tested positive for the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO, CALIF. -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 2015: Assembly member Brian W. Jones (R-Santee) hands Assembly member Tom Lackey (R-Palmdale) a bouquet, in Sacramento, Calif., on Sept. 10, 2015. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: D.A. sends hate crime case in Hollywood attack of transgender women back to LAPD
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A man arrested in connection with the caught-on-video robbery and beating of social media influencers Eden the Doll, Jaslene Whiterose and Joslyn Flawless has been released.
item.content:encoded: A man arrested in connection with the caught-on-video robbery and beating of social media influencers Eden the Doll, Jaslene Whiterose and Joslyn Flawless has been released.

Gavin Newsom's "Safter at Home," decree, it appeared to be working, as all is quiet along Hollywood Boulevard, near the TCL Chinese Theatre in Hollywood, CA, March 20, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California firestorm could claim more than 3,000 homes and structures

item.description: Nearly 2,000 structures have burned across California, and fire officials say that number could swell.
item.content:encoded: Nearly 2,000 structures have burned across California, and fire officials say that number could swell.

media:content.media:description: NAPA, CA - AUGUST 25: Burnt out wreckage at a property along CA-128 where the LNU Lightning complex fire tore through last week, photographed on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in Napa, CA. McNeal said his mother, Mary Hintemeyer, her boyfriend Leo McDermott and his son, Tom McDermott took refuge from the LNU Lightning Complex Fire in a makeshift fire shelter on their Napa County property, but the trio never made it out alive.

item.title: Shooting at party house leaves one dead, one injured in Beverly Crest
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Richard Winton
item.description: Two people were found shot, one fatally, after police were called to a Beverly Crest party home about 2:30 a.m. Wednesday, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Two people were found shot, one fatally, after police were called to a Beverly Crest party home about 2:30 a.m. Wednesday, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: Beverly Hills CA. AUGUST 26, 2020 - An investigation is underway after a shooting at a party house in the the 2200 block of San Ysidro Drive that left one person dead and sent another to a hospital early Wednesday morning, August 26, 2020. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)
